Basic Training July 1986
Captain Finnigan dropped me when I ran past him with my weapon and did not salute him.
My whole platoon dropped with me and our Drill Sgt Martin was so proud!
We had learned the true meaning of teamwork!
Basic Training Feb 1986 - Looking for my great friend Cindy Gladden who I went to both basic and AIT with at Fort Jackson.

BCT on Tank Hill (old wood barracks!) 1987. My son went to BCT on Tank Hill in 2013 with his barracks located pretty close to the same spot. It was pretty cool getting to go back for his gradation 26 years later.
Hurricane David, 1979 gave everyone the weekend off early.  Those of us who could not get home stayed on base and drank beer !

Ft Jackson was my entry to
The Army. Spent a week there...then put on a bus and went to Ft Benning Ga. Sand Hill!!! That's where the fun began!
BCT on Tank Hill 1987...Blood N Guts Platoon DS Sanford and DS Gonzales
BCT May 1997 A year after I graduated from HS. Followed in my grandpa's footsteps and joined the Army. He was so proud of me.
Basic training 1990, trained by airborne ds's. I learned I was capable of a lot more than I thought possible there
As a member of the NJ National Guard, I took my basic at Ft Jackson in 1967!!
15 July 1982 baby right of High School
Been there and done that and would do it again   1989

I went to JCLC, a JROTC camp, last week at Fort Jackson and we got to go to Victory Tower. It was absolutely terrifying at first but I loved it :) it helped me handle my fear of heights better

When I did my BCT at Fort Jackson, SC I did know that I was afraid of heights and never said anything to my Platoon Drill's and was terrified once I'd got on top.

But had a tremendous good time Repelling down the wall.

Thank You to all of the Training Cadre, you all are doing a great job with these SIT's.

I knew if I managed to climb the initial ladder up, I could complete it. No doubt that the Victory Tower training area loomed large in my mind as we marched throughout the area. Seems you could aways see it... it was like it mocked you until your opportunity to train there. Kudos to those that developed that training concept,  it really tested my ability to rely on my inner strength and overcoming obstacles. 30 years later and I'd like to meet the old beast again. :)  #VictoryStartsHere
Basic Training at Tank Hill June-August 1985. Best thing that could have happened to me! The entire experience was invaluable! I wouldn't have done it any differently! C-3-1
Wasn't scary at all when I went through it. Drill Sgt said do it, and I did. Very hard to fail it unless you give up. Also very hard to get hurt unless it's on purpose.

My daughter was afraid of heights too and didn't say anything because she wanted to get over her fear and thankfully she did not once but several times!! And I as a parent was amazed by the camaraderie while we stayed on base. It was truly an awesome experience!
We didn't have a victory tower, Drill Sargent Carruth is all we needed for 8weeks
Better yet, just give me a couple of drill Sgt. And I will get it done !!!
I'm terrified of heights, so naturally, I had to go first. Loved it!!!
*shudders* This was terrifying for me - I'm afraid of heights.
Let me know when I can come down to fort Jackson
My son is BCT 3/60 A Co right now, he should have already completed Victory Tower (if I have the timeline of training right) he's in white phase now.  Can't wait to hear him tell his story!

Victory Tower, what can I say about it. Like many others that have climbed the hollowed cargo nets and Repelled down the wall. I'll have too admit at first was absolutely terrifying to me at first because I am afraid of hights.  But I also knew that I needed to ignore those fears because I was determined not to fail at BCT on top of that it was my 25th birthday and I had to prove even us older "grandpa's " could do it. It ended up being one of my favorite memories of Basic. 
Delta 1-34 3rd plt mighty Eagles Always Forward. (November 2001- February 2002)
If I did that today, you would have to send in a special ops rescue team for me !!
Can not wait to be there later this year! Counting the days till I conquer victory Tower!! #excited
Wish our son could go through it all again
Been there done that.

So how does that really help someone whom may have been considered weaker in the beginning then grow into the strong soldier-and NOT be the MOS  he or she actually deserved!   It's another way to "Fill" slots and MOS's that people don't want....

I feel at first view, that this will be a rigorous and resource intensive (new) process.  Hopefully, it will not become burdensome.  However, I have confidence in the doctrinaires and ground-level practitioners who are engaged in transforming trainees into a newly-minted soldiers.

I had been privileged (for over three decades) to work within the cantonment of a major Army training base; therefore, I had a peripheral seat in observing  Army (training) practices for preparing young citizens to succeed in their military experience. 

I can enthusiastically and categorially state: ?The Army has been getting better in preparing people to succeed.  Back in the ?bad old days (mid 70?s)? when I went through ?Basic?, the doctrine (my interpretation) was ?break?um down and rebuild them the Army way?.  Effective as a method?  Not so much.

Through the years, the Army has increasingly found better methods to build on the existing strengths of incoming personnel.  I know that the new soldiers of the 21st century are soldiers better prepared to handle the mission.

Its called relaxin jackson for a reason. My biggest challenge when I arrived to my first duty station was not being prepared. It would help if they implenented and allowed more hands on training on comms and weapons. Most seasoned soldiers and ncos looked at me and said "figure it out yourself" or would get frustrated when you asked questions. In my situation, I never actually worked or did anything associated with my MOS. The first week at my duty station, I got thrown into Tac. It would have paid off if I had received more 11B training before being thrown into an 11B dominated tac platoon. It doesn't bother me now, I adapted like we all do and if made me a stronger soldier in the long run. When I went through BCT, it seemed like most drill sergeants were burnt out and were rushing soldiers through training. Just so you know, if you are thinking about joining, I'd go 11B. Regardless, I do not regret a thing I did or the fellow comrades I served with.
If a solider doesn't pass basic...will the parents be informed if there going home?
If I want to get pictures from when I was in boot camp how do I do that?

And get rid of all this stress bull@#$%. If you can't handle the stress of a Drill Sargent screaming two inches from your face, bad breath and spit, then how the hell are you gonna handle the ultimate stress of war!?!
If they are well trained, then they will be fit and disciplined. If the trainer is a professional, it all comes together.
More is better!

I want to say Thank You to Spc. Pablo Arroyo and the Arroyo family for serving Our Nation. Especially now as they they're supporting you while you serve now. I wish you Good Luck on your future Training and on going to OCS to become an Officer.  Be sure to remember although you were an Enlisted Soldier first that you should always follow the advice of your Senior NCO's of whatever Unit you are assigned to. Officer's might Command it's the Enlisted that run's the Service's.  In the Past I'd had one Officer that I'd truly respected as a newly 2nd Lt.
It's simply because of something that he'd done that I'd never ever seen or heard of for an Officer.  Then men and I were doing some heavy lifting and we ended up being a person short, that newly young 2nd Lt. actually got his hands dirty and helped us with that Task. Mind you after that day the men and I had much respect for him and whenever he'd asked for us to do a Task we'd made sure that Task got done within a timely manner.

But Good Luck to you and be Safe.  From a Fmr. Service Member who'd Trained at the Fort Jackson, SC Instillation.

A bit of background for those commenting: 2016 will mark the second phase of a five-year plan approved by Congress under which service members receiving BAH will pay an increasing percentage of average off-base housing costs out of their own pockets.

Under that plan, the portion of housing costs borne by BAH recipients is increasing by one percentage point a year, which means that next year, they will pay 2 percent of national average housing costs out of pocket, with their housing allowance covering the rest. By 2019, that cost-sharing formula will rise to a maximum of 5 percent.

I've been "around for a while" and I believe the following:  You likely have gotten the impression that the military is in a steep trajectory of downsizing personnel and resources.  Personally, my gut, tells me that that we are in the lull before the storm.  Support our troops and for "goodness sake", tell congress, the senate and our potential POTUS that they had better honor our Service Men & Women, especially since NONE of them (w/few exceptions) have EVER served.  If they rattle the saber, they had "#&*!" well better know how to use it and they had better learn "Quickly" what it (really) means to wear the uniform. 

And, by the way, Fort Jackson and the troops assigned to it are critical to our Nation in training soldiers in the methods that will facilitate their success on the battlefield.   SUPPORT OUR TROOPS!
#Army #FortJackson #Troops #Military #Congress #Senate #Rrepublican #Democrate

I'm sure your mind is open to learning as much as u can so when u get out you will get a job to support your family in the way that you want.  Remember God is with you always. "What I learned about myself is that whenever I decide to do something, I can do it, and ? that when it comes to working with others, I am better working in a team than as an individual." Congratulations on being part of something bigger than you. Spc Gary Wu  your not old my friend. I joined at the age of 37 on November 10, 2009. I don't know what it is I just love the Army. Something  about the discipline and training,and of course the team work. I finished my five years on April 10-2015. However I joined the Army national guard on October 23-2015. I still wanted to give back and be a part of something bigger than me. I still can outrun soldiers half my age. Age is just a number. It's all in the state of mind. I never fell out of a run while I was in for 5 years. It takes a big hearted person to join the Army. Congratulations young man.

For those needing the roads corresponding to the gates, Gate 1 - Jackson Blvd., exit 10 off of I-77. Gate 2 - Forest Dr., exit 12 off of I-77. Gate 4 - Percival Road, exit 14 off of I-77. Gate 5 - Leesburg Rd.
Gate 1 is Fort Jackson Blvd that comes into the traffic circle. Gate 2 is the main gate on Forest. Gate 4 is off Percival. Gate 5 is off Semmes that goes into Leesburg.
For those who are confuse. Can you name the streets these gates are at please?

While this is great news can you please explain to the guards that were working at gate one that this information was not distributed to the general public until after 9 am this morning and there was no need for his poor attitude and sarcastic remarks toward those of us just trying to get to work who were unaware that the other gates had been opened. Also that yes traffic was by passing gate 2 coming off of i77 south due to the traffic being backed up past the Decker road on ramp and none of us knowing that the Percival road gate was open. That is awesome. I am so glad somebody is calling this in for the families who planned to celebrate their soldiers and now can't. Yes, we know that soldiering is sacrificing, but no one expected this or knew the magnitude of how it would affect the out of town families of the graduating classes. People don't have money to throw at plane tickets they can't use. Hopefully the airlines are more understanding as time progresses and honor the requests for refunds for those who have no use for vouchers. Flights are not merchandise. People shouldn't be made to take vouchers like a no-receipt purchase at Walmart to be used "in case" you have somewhere else to fly. Frequent travelbis not something that everyone does.

Those of us who live here and weren't even impacted from the floods are staying put and not going out unnecessarily. The roads may look safe, but they are not. Your son/daughter/wife/husband signed on the dotted line, so from here forward, the needs of the Army come first. There's an old saying that "if the Army wanted you to have a wife/family, they would have issued you one."  Don't start your graduate's career by being a "problem family member". They are adults and as adults some things just don't go your way. I'm proud to be the spouse of a retired servicemember and mother of a NG Soldier. Whatever my husband wanted to do to advance his career, I was behind him 100%. The same goes for my son. My golden rule as an Army wife, "Never make promises, never tell your children a date when daddy will be home". Every homecoming was a surprise.

I know this was an extremely difficult decision but safety for all comes first and I believe this is a good call.  Congrats to all the graduates, welcome to the Army family and hugs to all the families missing their loved one!

Maybe have an indoor ceremony just for the Soldiers, and still have the videos recorded so the families may see it at a future time. I know this is so mentally hard on new Soldiers, and I really feel for you, but, you DID A FANTASTIC job, and in your hearts you will always know what you did was top notch. You military family will be with you at this time.

I am sorry that the friends and families of these Soldiers who worked so hard for this achievement are not able to be there for this wonderful day of what I am sure will be many.  I would like all the family, friends and most definitely soldiers to know We are PROUD of you, and we thank you for your hard work, determination, strength, courage and sacrifices for our Country.  Thank you!
Some organizations don't get the help where they need it most.  We are so thankful to have Fort Jackson close to us, and know that your loved are loved and appreciated.
Much love and prayers for those soldiers and their families.....
Tough decision but clearly the right call.  I feel for all the families and SIT's that were looking forward to these events.  I hope they have another opportunity to reunite soon.

I understand that it is very disappointing to not be able to see your children/spouses/friend/family member; but some are failing to understand that we are in a state of emergency here. Our landscape has change and for those who know Columbia well have a hard time maneuvering; can you imagine if your not from here? 9 weeks is nothing in the military (not to be rude just being honest). What happens when they're deployed or stationed overseas? I had two children (4 year old and 5 month old) and a husband deployed for a year! . We are under a water advisory, we are being ask to conserve water, we have road collapsing, we have a curfew for our safety, and quite frankly those who don't understand seem very selfish. There are residents here who are homeless or lost majority of their personal items. When the soldiers are settled in AIT, they normally can get a weekend pass. That's what I would look forward to.
It is the right call for Columbia and Fort Jackson.
If family is already in the are, will they be able to visit their soldier before they leave for AIT?

For folks asking about child care, here's what will be open tomorrow and Friday (for children of key and essential personnel ONLY):
  Lee Rd CDC, Hood St CDC, and Hood St School Age Ctr (SAC). Please direct all K-Middle School children to the Hood St SAC.  All preschoolers should be brought to Lee Rd CDC first. Preschoolers may be directed to Hood St CDC if/when Lee reaches capacity. 
  Please note that the combined capacity of these 3 facilities is just around 200 children. Care provided this week, as FJ slowly recovers from the emergency, is intended for mission essential personnel only. Thanks for your understanding.

While I understand you are all upset, please be respectful. 5 local lives were lost today, homes are destroyed, businesses have been lost, and roads have been washed away. Most of the interstates around Columbia are currently closed. It's a very tragic and very real situation here currently. Fort Jackson had to make a decision based on safety.
Heart felt prayers to all our soldiers in Ft. Jackson who are out and about and also those bunkered down in the barracks. Texas is praying for you!

Prayers for SC, Ft. Jackson and East Coast. My son who is a graduate from Ft. Jackson is thankful that this did not happen to him. Not because of the cancellation,  but the disappointment as a Army soldier seeing these post. He stated if this was his battalion,  he would never had wanted a ceremony. He would have been more upset if his resources were not used to help the community instead of standing in formation.   It is a honorable  that your son's and daughters completed the training and are soldiers of this GREAT nation.  A Nation that has communities,  states, and families suffering so much more than the absence of a ceremony or phone call. They are suffering lost lives, homes, etc. I understand disappointed hearts that you have...but I know for a fact, if this had been my son's battalion the disappointment would have been him against me if I had posted opposition of the absolutely correct decision that was made. Our children hearts are changed in basic training to a caring, compassionate and giving soul with a clear understanding of what is truly important in life. Maybe it is time for parents to take a deep breath and learn from these soldiers.  I am proud of your SIT as many are. Hooah SIT'S ! Always Moving forward !
My heart breaks for the soldiers and families who won't get to see each other. Praying for all of them.

This isn't a way for anyone to take anything away from any Soldier. There was a devastating natural disaster. Several military and civilian personnel in and around the area cannot even access Fort Jackson because roadways in and out all over the state are impassable.  Post is currently being staffed by essential personnel only. I am not an employee of Fort Jackson,  so I can't say for certain anything  on behalf of post, but canceling graduation is not a decision which was reached with ease. Post cannot support visitors and does not have the available staff to support a ceremony. Two dams on Fort Jackson, itself, were complete losses. Emergency Management on post has been working non-stop to mitigate the proper procedures for the Fort Jackson community and its safety.  Please do not worry that something bad has happened to your Soldier. Enough time has passed that you would already be notified if they were in imminent danger or had sustained injuries. "Stronger emphasis on physical readiness" = no more sending PT fails or fatbodies on to AIT? At DLI you routinely saw kids in-process who were beyond tape limits, who failed first diagnostic APFT. BCT cadre who "pass'em on to become someone else's headache" are the culprits here. What a bad lesson in army ethics this teaches!!!

Peer reviews? An opinion of your fellow boot campers formed on what you've witnessed in so structured and artificial an environment for all of what 8 wks or 12 wks? What value is this? Otherwise I do feel trainees should early on be introduced to an AAR process. I'd even intentionally orchestrate a "bad" or "less than optimal" outcome --chow mermites are cold, cattle car shows up later or earlier than planned-- and then see how they deal with those.

My father, Robert E Wayson, was a Drill Sergeant at Fort Jackson from about 1964 or 65 until about 1968.  There was a building that used to be not too far from what was the old gate off Percival Rd. My father painted the company mascot on the side of that building.  I believe it was a fox, maybe.  My mother, my brother, and I would sometimes pick him up after work there and the tear gas would be hanging in the air.  It was awful!  I would love to find a photo of that long gone building.  I wonder if it would be in one of those basic training yearbooks.

No people. It's because the paper (and therefore it's webpages) are run by civilians, who are effectively on unpaid leave until further notice and under orders to not do anything pertaining to their jobs aside from changing messages/emails/webpages to say that they are closed until further notice. Just because it's FB and a free page doesn't mean anything for the people who run it, it's still related to their job.

Google/Research. It's your friend. Military Pay is protected. So, therefore, Yes-your loved ones will get paid. But, payments could be late. This is all part of what's going on. It's something that happens all of the time. I remember it was going to happen to me in April of 2011 I was at an army school. They were worried. I told them I'd been on orders. Funds were already paid out. Therefore I was good to go.

FORT JACKSON, S.C. -- Fort Jackson will have new gate hours beginning July 8 as thel federal civilian workers furlough period begins.

The furlough period will begin July 8 and end Sept. 30. During the furlough period, civilian employees will experience one furlough day per week.

The pending furloughs further reduce the number of security guards, which requires that gate hours of operation be altered through September.

Fort Jackson Gate Hours (starting July 8):

Gate 1: 
5 a.m. to 1 p.m.; inbound and outbound traffic, Monday through Friday
3:30 to 6 p.m.; outbound traffic, Monday through Friday
Closed on weekends

Gate 2: 
Open around the clock, seven days a week 
Commercial traffic on weekends only

Gate 4: 
5 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Monday through Friday
Closed om weekends
Commercial traffic must use Gate 4 on weekdays.

Gate 5:
Closed

Served with the 39th Infantry (4th Bn 39th Inf 9th Inf Div Vietnam 1967-'68)  Found this memorial for one of our older brothers who fought in WWII.  Didn't know where else to send it.  LEST WE FORGET.

My Father, who was 19 yo at the time, left the UP of Michigan, became an Army Scout (he ran Track/Field in HS) and was in the 1st wave of D-Day, at Omaha Beach.  He made it but could not locate anyone else in his unit.  The rest may have died.  He was then captured by the Germans.  German POWs fared better than those captured by the Japanese, as was my Uncle, in the Bataan Death March (which was what prompted my Father to join the Army).  Our military is amazing.

I would like to clarify a few things about this article. First of all, women have been working on the Bradley Fighting Vehicle for DECADES. I held the MOS of 45K (Tank and Turret Repairer) since 1995 and I am not even close to being the first woman awarded this MOS. The bradley used to broken into two types of mechanics. The Hull Mechanics and the Turret Mechanics.  The only thing she is the "first" of is the first woman to be ASSIGNED to a line unit, not attached.  Please fix this article. You are disrespecting so many hard working women who have "trailblazed" for years to make way for this young woman now.
Congratulations Pvt Verstein!  Ft Jackson still blazing the trail!  I went to Basic there in 1985 up on Tank Hill.  After 20 years I retired.

Congrats for paving the way young Soldier. That is what I did when I was first enlisted Bardley fighting vehicle systems turret mechanic. I am so glad to see the Army is changing and allowing  women to do some of these different jobs. Again Congratulations young Soldier for your service and sacrifice!!!
I along with Sabrina Cady, held the MOS of a 45K and repaired many Bradley Fighting Vehicles, M1 tanks and Artillery.

I know how hard it is. Once your soldier arrives at reception it could be up to a week before you hear from them, trust me if something were wrong with your soldier you would have been contacted.  My daughter left on 18 October and im so happy she will be home for Christmas. Be patient they will call you soon and by that time hopefully they will have an address where you can write them. My husband was a drill sergeant before but I was still stressing out even though he explained to me how things work. As a parent or loved one you will worry regardless. I am very proud of my future soldier. I am looking forward to graduation on 17 January. As an Army wife of 20 years my family is no stranger to the military and we know how hard it can be to be separated from your loved ones, but they are doing a very admirable thing by enlisting in the military. I'm very proud of all the future soldiers and I hope and pray each one of you will be hearing from your loved ones soon. Take advantage of the Facebook pages for whatever company your soldier is in. They post pictures often. You never know you may see your future soldier in some of them. I look forward to seeing the pictures. I stalk the FB page daily checking to see if new pics were posted so that I can hopefully catch a glimpse of my baby girl.

What does it mean they will be charged for this leave??
- Charged means it will come out of their leave bank - like vacation hours.
@jennifer. they earn 2.5 days of leave every month. In which when they take leave they are charged leave from the days they earn from being in the Army
Does the Exodus time extend their training? As in, does it add that time to their stay at Jackson? Also, are they paid for that time if they do not go on leave?

Ok so they told him he has to come home for 2 weeks.  So if they give him the 2.5 in December he will have 15 days of vacation. So if he only had say 10 days the wood charge him 5 days of pay because he didn't have enough saved up?

My son did his training at fort jackson around christmas. He did come home for ten days. They are charged vacation time. They have someone that will help them with purchasing there tickets. I know my son didnt pau for his tickets up front they took it directly out of his first paycheck in january. When my son was there it did not extend there training cause exodus is figured into the weeks of training. So weather or not they go home they still get the time off just some chose to stay on base so they dont lose time off, for money reasons or because they dont want to break the concentration
Yes they do end up in what they call the hole. Which means they will use time they havent earned yet. Once they get to ait they will earn that time back

They still get paid when at home the time they use and lose is vacation time. Its kinda like paid vacation. So say they only have earned 5 days they will get to borrow 5 more days so that they get the full ten days at home. But if they chose not to go home they wont get charged vacation time and they wont end up in the hole. They will give them stuff to do on base.
is this the same at all bases?
I believe so, i also believe that the army is the only branch of the military that does this but i could be wrong

they do not have to take this leave. They can stay there at the base and not have to repay the cost of the ticket home and keep their leave for when they get done with all their training. The airforce does this to but only during Tech School training.
my son is army but is going to eglin afb for the remainder of his training.....i think he will be getting leave at that time too
Exactly i know when my son was there all of the soldiers went home but maybe about 10 of them. They can use the rec room and watch movies and just chill
What is it like If we stay???
The soldiers ought save their leave for when they get out of ait or until they have 30 days. 15 days of leave is too short.

Only training bases have exodus...rest of army posts do what is called block leave, and it is not guaranteed. It just depends where you are and what the current mission is or if your rear detachment for a deployed unit. But no all posts do not get exodus.

If you stay on fort Jackson during christmas you will be detailed out to do cleaning, yard work, cleaning, painting etc. you still need to earn your pay. You will get Christmas and new years off but basically rest of the time the army can put you to work.
Soldiers who stay during EXODUS will have minor details to perform, but the battalion they are assigned to will also have fun activies planned for them as well.

@Adriana: There often seems to be a time lag in their mail at first. But you may want to go to the Facebook page for his company/battalion and make sure you are using the correct address.

@Monica, here is what the 2-13th says about mail on their FB page Notes:

RANK Last Name, First Name MI
____ Co 2-13 IN Regt
4380 Magruder Ave
Ft. Jackson, SC 29207

**Add the soldiers platoon number to the BACK of the envelope, adding a fifth line on the front to include the platoon information confuses the ?readers? at the post office which slows down the time in the mail getting to your soldier.**
So your SIT's address would be the above, but with "A Co." in place of the blank in the 2nd line, and the platoon #1 written on the back of the envelope.

He is with the 165th Infantry Regiment. The address will be Charlie Co., 2nd Battalion, 39th Infantry Regiment. You will need his platoon number though in order to complete the infromation. I hope this bit of information helps!

My son called and said he was in echo 239... That's all I got as well.. How can I send him mail?
You will need a Platoon Number, Company Alphabet Letter (A. B. C. D. or E.) , a Battalion Number (1, 2, or 3) and lastly a Infantry Regiment number ( 34, 39, 60 ,or 13)
My son is in F company, is that usual?  You only list thru E.

Yes I do apologize there is a F company Karen Backman Burkhalter. Military Phonetic Alphabet for those letters are A-Alpha, B- Bravo , C- Charlie, D-Delta, E-Echo and F- Foxtrot this is how they are recognized so there is no misunderstanding in how they sound when spoken amoung military members.

Michelle Palmer Kalahar your address should be written as follows: Rank, Last Name, First Name of Soldier, Echo Company, (Platoon Number), 2nd Battalion, 39th Infantry Regiment, and street address of the unit will follow. Do you have the street we can get that for you?

When my son called all i got was 239.  Will i get a letter with his full address?

He will either give the unit information when he calls, or you can expect to receive a letter. Most new Soldiers are nervous and learning the new military jargon at the same time as the family, but at a different rate. Because everything is happening so fast for them, so they will copy the unit information down in a hurry and likely miss a few numbers and or others will write and you can use thier return address on the envelope mailed to write letters.

Unfortunately I am unfamiliar with the information that you are referring to on the back of the envelope. To find out his address , please contact the post locator at 803-751-7671. They are expecting calls from families within this unit.

The Drill Sergeant of the Year competition is one of the most physically demanding and mentally tough challenges any Soldier can face in a United States Army competition. For four days, these competitors must perform and master all associated tasks and drills from Basic Combat Training. To win and be named the Drill Sergeant of the Year, they must not only be experts in training Soldiers, but also be the best of the best and rise above the competition.
The candidates are also tested on their knowledge of various soldiering tasks and how they teach those skills and techniques to new trainees. The final step in the selection process is an appearance before a board of senior command sergeants major to answer questions on leadership and training.

It varies for each Battalion, but according to www.jackson.army.mil it states:
The day before graduation (typically Wednesday) is designated as 
"Family Day." Family Day activities begin at Hilton Field at 9 a.m. The battalion commander meets with family members and friends of graduating Soldiers to discuss the Soldier?s recent experiences and answer questions. Family and friends will also meet the unit's drill sergeants and observe demonstrations of Soldier skills.
Stay off Strom Thurmond Blvd and away from the PX

Their unit leaders are supposed to bring them to the travel office so they can book a flight home. The cost will be taken out of their pay. The travel office is supposed to be good, call them if you have questions.  It says that they should book the flight to avoid confusion and mixups.

I spoke to the travel center today.  Families are able to book the flight and make the bus arrangements for their leave.  They did stress that your SIT needs to know this before they come to the travel center, if two trips are booked, there are NO refunds.  I called with these questions and they were very helpful.

Kelly What is so hard about AIT? Please explain..

Ms. Clopper i just want the new soldiers to continue to live the Army Core Values and live the Soldiers Creed. They will not have drill sergeants watching their every move and no matter what they are soldiers first and they need to do what is right. They had the best training and now they just need to continue on to AIT with the same discipline they have worked so hard to achieve these last few months. They will have guidence from the cadre but it is up to the soldier to maintain their military bearing. For many soldiers this is their first time on their own and AIT allows for more freedom and it can be difficult sometimes to always to do the right thing. As long as the soldiers surround themselves with the right people and remember that although they are given the privilege of leaving post and having weekends off and getting to enjoy themselves their number one priority is to continue to train.

Great issue, I am wondering why it is called the Torchlight tattoo celebration, what does the tattoo stand for? Just curious.
ditto that :)  what does the tattoo stand for?
You can't give blood for 6 months after a tat, so I wouldn't think that's it! If so I think is wrong!

tattoo noun (pl. tattoos) 1. an evening drum or bugle signal recalling soldiers to their quarters. 2. a military display consisting of music, marching, and exercises. [from Dutch taptoe, shutting off of taps, signalling the closing of taverns at the end of the day].
Over the years, the process became more of a show.

I just found this site. I am wondering about AIT!  Our daughter just graduated Feb. 24th from BCT, D3/60th, Wardawgs.   How strict is AIT?  I assume they do pt and have long days but we really haven't gotten much info. and haven't heard from our daughter only once over the week-end.  They started processing Monday but haven't heard anything from her since.  Do they have to earn privileges, like using their phones, do they have curfews, etc.  Any info. would be helpful, thanks!

@Susan:  My son, Spc. Kasheta,Co. F, Warlords, also graduated from Ft. Jackson on Feb. 24th and is doing his AIT at Ft. Meade.  He has his cell phone and seems to be able to call when he gets the time which is only at night.  There are restrictions for a while as far as not being able to go off base which I think has to be earned.  I am not sure if it differs at each AIT base.  Your solder is probably very tired by the end of the day.  My son told me they get him up at 4 am and he is kept fairly busy throughout the day even though his actual classes don't start for another week or so.  I hope this helps and congratulations on your new American Solder!

Susan, it does differ a little from one AIT unit to another--but in general, yes, they continue to "phase up" and earn more privileges throughout AIT. They get their personal electronics back at the end of BCT, and at AIT generally can use them except when on duty, they earn the privilege of leaving post for the day & then overnight on weekends, etc. My husband had a couple of 4-day weekend passes during AIT, and while he could not go too far away (250 miles max, I think?), we could visit and get away from post.

So it's much different from BCT. Being able to call and Skype and text is a real treat after the silence of BCT!
I guess things have really changed since 1999... We never had electronics that we were able to use even through AIT... we had phone calls on the weekends and that was it... How nice it must be now..

Thank you Rosanna and Jaye!  You have helped alot!  She is doing her AIT at Fort Jackson so atleast she didn't have to go elsewhere.  I am sure we will hear from her soon!  Bless you for the detailed information and congratulations on your new American Soldiers, as well!  Wasn't Family Day and Graduation a spectacular experience?  I miss the River Raiders site, but happy to have found this one.  Take Care!!

The proposed 6 events are:

Long Jump (2 x 5 second jumps)
Power Squat (1 minute)
Heel Hook (1 minute)
Shuttle Run (6 x 25 yard sprints)
Push-Ups (1 minute)
1 Mile Run (As fast as you can)- NO PACING ANOTHER SOLIDER IS ALLOWED

CLIMBING DRILL 1, EXERCISE 2: HEEL HOOK

Purpose: This exercise develops the ability to raise the legs from a hanging position and hook the feet securely on the bar (Figure 9-25).

Starting Position: Extended hang using the alternating grip, left or right.

Cadence: SLOW

Count:
Pull with the arms and curl the lower body toward the bar. Raise the feet above the bar and interlock them securely around the bar.
Return to the starting position.

I would really like for someone to report how the families of the graduating soldiers liked having their event moved three hours later to accomodate the First Lady, thereby costing them several hours out of their time with their soldier. They only have until 8:30 PM before the graduate has to be back in barracks!

I would like to hear how many of these families had to stand out in the parking lot at Hilton Field and strain to maybe hear the audio as their loved ones graduated, because the seats in that small venue were filled by the "general public" that the event was opened up to?

If a political figure really wanted to honor the graduating soldiers, they could have kept the event on schedule and not invited the public into what should have been a special event for the soldiers and their families.

I don't care if it's Michelle Obama or the ghost of Abe Lincoln. It shouldn't have been done, and I am GLAD it wasn't done when my daughter graduated in September.

Denise, I was there, I spoke to many, many families whose loved ones graduated today. They considered it an HONOR that the First Lady of the USA spoke today. There was plenty of seating for EVERYBODY (in fact, a row of bleachers in front of us was empty!) 

I sat in the very back row of the bleachers, and I heard everything fine. Believe me, no one was complaining today, and I'm sure they don't appreciate you complaining for them.

i've heard that if my soldier takes the whole exodus leave, that he will go into the negative with leave time when he gets out of training, meaning he will have to make up that time...is this true? or do they get the leave time during exodus no strings attached?

Leave is charged to your soldier.  This could put them negative, depending on how long they have been in.  Your soldier gets 30 days of leave a year.  They will be able to use 30 days total - this includes the leave time they use for exodus.  
Your soldier is also responsible for their transportation to and from their training location.

They will get leave. This is the only time you are allowed to go into the negative on leave days. They then pay back the negative as you earn it. You will not be able to take additional leave until the negative ia paid back. Exception would be home town recruiting and that is done at the end of AIT   This is not counted a's leave and is 2 weeks a's well.
Sonja- No, they won't pay..it is up to the soldier or their family to pay, from what I can see.

thats interesting...the Drill sergeants have been replaced by Platoon Sergeants in AIT and they work just as hard if not harder than the Drill Sergeants, and the big kicker is they get no DRILL PAY....talk about BS...lets see just like a basic training drill, I am at work at the butt crack of dawn and I dont leave till 2000 or 2100, so thats give or take 15 to 16 hrs a day, but I also get on the platform and instruct all day and do my tactical training in the evening and on weekends..the only day we get off is Sunday unless we have duty.  Oh yeah, for our platoons which average 65 to 70 in size we get ONE Platoon Sergeant and if I am lucky a Squad Leader to help in the classrooom, but a lot of the times they are civilians..hmmmm  I am thinking we are the ones who work the hardest...especially for basic pay...and those who say well you didnt go to DS school..thats true...but I did go to the Platoon sergeants course, Staff and Fac, have the combatives and all other certifications that Drills to include Range OIC qualifications, unit armorer, UPL, all my HAZMAT quals and oh yeah Master Driver and Master Fitness..so no...the army needs to realize the real reason they replaced the drill from AIT was only to save a freaking buck and screw over the Platoon sergeants...so Drill sergeants do no more work than Platoon Sergeants..

I agree and disagree. I am a DS wife and my husband was deployed for 2 years and I saw him 2 times in 2 years.  Thats really hard.  DS's are training these boys to go to battle and have to wonder every day if they taught them enough to keep them alive and thier wives live with that too. So its hard all the way around for all Army wives.

@Migdalia, we have all been army wives that's how we get here, our husbands get this not by choice. We were stationed for 5 years in Ft. Cambpell KY and I know what deployments are and how hard they are on the family. I have 3 girls, beleive me I know what it is to be left behind with a new born and have your husband come home to meet his daugther and do everything on my own. This is more or less my life now. My husband began his duty as a DS just 6 months ago, this is like when my husband got deployed for 15 months, but the difference is that you have to deal with the fact that they are here but you can't count on them 95% of the time, you know when they leave but not when they get out. It's hard on the family, just like a deployment. All military spouses deserve recognition, but, to be honest, when my husband was just a SGT in the regular Army I knew that most of the time he would be home by 5:30pm the latest on less he had staff duty, here my kids don't get to see their dad before they go to bed unless he is on the last 3 weeks of the cycle. We don't deal with deployments for only 2 years 3 the most if they are allowed to extend and then back to regular army. I talk from experience, we have been in for almos 10years 7months...But, I know that it's hard either way...

I am not disrespecting the DS Wives..I was merely making aside point about how DS have the hardest job in the army...that is totally wrong..all I was stating that DS have it no harder then Platoon Sergeant who push out the final product to operational Army.  As for the military spouses...I have no probs with them..I totally agree that its a tough job on you all, but its like comparing apples to oranges on whos job is tougher or not...shouldnt be about the military job being harder or easier than being a stay at home spouse or even a working spouse...bottom line SPOUSES (male or female)chose to marry into the military and made the coice themselves to stay a civilian or join the military raksa themselves...agree?  Well I have had Soldiers who have served under and with me in theater whose hard working spouse was out cheating on him/her while they financed it under their noses.  and I have also seen the supportive ones as well...it is about 50/50..trust me I have counseled many Soldiers who were losing it while deployed over a cheating spouse (male and female)..so I dont know who is cheating or not on this forum, but hey we all make choices everyday, and we make choices freely...nobody made you marry a Soldier and nobody made that same Soldier join the army...we deal with the cards we are dealt...just my opinion.  
yeah for the record I never bashed the spouses like some of you all jumped my crap about...re-read my post, I was just making a point that equal work shoudl be equal pay...Im not mad at the DS branch, hell I fall under that branch myself..Im just saying the higer ups need to recognize the jobs that warrant equal pay.

ann williams it takes forever to figure it out and for the D.S to post info u need to figure out his company info like my husband was a roadrunner family bravo company1/61st inf reg 1st platoon pitbulls but b4 we had to go under bulldogs to find pics of training be patient things will post and get that company info if ur family is lucky hes in a good company    they say they cant call but for good behavior and good training 4 the week on sundays my husband always got to call home he just graduated 6/25 from ft jackson keeping my fingers crossed

@Ann: they usually will get to call home within the first few days to let you know they arrived safely, after that, phone calls are earned. I ended up getting about a total of 4 or 5 phone calls from my son during Basic Combat Training. They don't tell them WHO to call so if you don't get a call he may be calling someone else (ie; girlfriend). Hope this helped:)  Some of the Companies also set up a Facebook page. Check into that because they keep you updated on what your soldier is doing and post lots of pictures. I got to see many pictures of my son during his training at at the Victory Concert. Plus the families support one another. It was a God send!
I agree Jaye I served in the Marines my brother the Navy now my oldest son went Army nephew Air Force.

hey my fiance left june 28th. he is a bulldog. he has been able to call me alot. he is on the white phase now they go in 3 phases white is the middle one. now he gets to call me every sunday last sunday he got like 11min on the phone length changes everthime. it all depends on the address what group he is in have you or anyone gotten a letter from him yet? they have reccession thing first joeys was only like 5 days but it can take up to ten depending on how many people all got there at the same time. joey was able to have his cell phone during that time so he texted me all the time. letters take some time. there barracks collect all letters every coulple days then they get sent to a diffrent buliding on base were all barracks letters go then they get organized sent to another buliding then organized more then from there sent to a reagular post office off base. so letters can take a while to come depending on when writen and we dont always get them in order or ill get like 3 in the mail one day then the next day get 2 and not get anymore for like ten days. it changes alot. I was told that they put pics up of every group some pics cant see faces well but others you can try this  http://www.facebook.com/pages/Columbia-SC/1st-Battalion-61st-Infantry-Regiment-Roadrunners-Fort-Jackson-SC/128896666647?ref=search#!/pages/Columbia-SC/1st-Battalion-61st-Infantry-Regiment-Roadrunners-Fort-Jackson-SC/128896666647?v=photos&ref=search&__a=3&ajaxpipe=1 then once you figure out what group like joey is the bulldogs you can maybe find pics. ask in the first letter you write. hope at least some of that helped

my husband was a pitbull but his photo links were under bulldogs if that helps anyone it took forever to figure it out good luck to all at bct keep ur head up stay focused and always remember be army strong that goes for all the family members

My son graduated on May 28th.  Seeing him on Family Day and Graduation were 2 of the best days of my life.  I am so very proud of the young man he is becoming.  I won't kid you the 10 weeks he was at BCT were very hard.  Him being away and having little contact with him, phone calls were few & far between & 5 minutes if I was lucky, but did get letters from him on a regular basis & those are priceless.  He is doing fantastic, growing into such a responsible, respectful young man.  Hang in there, it is not any easier on them.  Send lots of letters & tell them how much you love them & how proud of them you are, the changes in them when you finally do see them on Family day is worth it all!  Good luck to everyone.

my husband graduated 5/28/10 family day and graduation were the best. the experience was priceless, especially when you go and search for your soldier down in the field on family day, VERY EMOTIONAL!!! letters, letters, letters write lots of letters!!! it helps get them by. i recomend sending at least one per day. ft. jackson postal system runs slow. if you send a letter today it can take up to 10 days before your soldier gets it, especially if they just got there. my husband was in bravo co. they day he graduated everyone in his platoon knew who i was because i set so many letters. LOL i litterally sent about 100 inspirational and motivational letters. FYI don't write about any drama back home they don't need that, stick to positive letters. My son graduated from Fort Jackson in May. I was there with my older son. It was an awesome experience that I will cherish forever. He then went to AIT at Fort Jackson, OK, and for a few weeks, he really missed the friends he has made during BT. Now, he is enjoying AIT, and just got his orders for after AIT. He will graduate AIT on June 25th and I will be there as well, then he gets to come home for three weeks. Then he has to go to Korea!!! WE have had mixed feelings about that, but now we are cool with it. He will gain tons of experience!! I am so proud of him....I was just like all of you..wondering about letters, phone calls, etc. In Basic, don't expect anything!! Really...they are very strict and you may not get any calls and just a few letters..if any. Don't feel bad..that is how it is with all the recruits! Before Graduation, the army will send you information on everything you need to know, so don't worry about that as well. Bring a camera and look forward to lots of HUGS and FUN!! You will be so proud of your soldier!!

I start basic on May 17th. How do I know which company I'll be in? At reception? Also I go to OCS after BCT. When will they send me over to Fort Benning for OCS? Friday? Saturday? Any info would MUCH appreciated. Thank you

Steven,
  I went to basic in Jackson in 2000. I was in reception for a couple of days to get processing done. If it is still the same you will find out in reception were you will be for your actual basic training. You will most likely go to Benning the day you graduate basic. Good luck to you.
Thanks so much for the info. Kind of in the dark on some things ya know. Just trying to plan.

Steven.. you won't know the company until after you get done at reception mainly because it all depends on which unit is picking up when you finish there. They will transport you the following Saturday after graduation unless you have an immediate family member take you to OCS. Good Luck and thank you for serving! :)
YOu can only travel in POV to OCS if it is with in so many miles of Fort Jackson.  I think Benning is in that range
My boyfriend just left reception yesterday..does anyone know when he will be able to call me and how often they can receive letters?

Not sure about phone calls - my daughter was at Ft Jackson 2 years ago so don't know if things have changed or not - BUT she did say be careful about total number of letters - they had to do push ups in order to get their mail sometimes....Drill Sgts had a blast when they received lots of mail....I thought we were doing a good thing all sending separate letters  :-)  but try to put them in one envelope so they won't know he's getting so many
You or someone in his family will probably receive a letter from him soon telling you he arrived safely and what his address is.

My boyfriend arrived wednesday night and was in processing until this morning... Said going to basic today. Still not sure about phone calls. They let them use phones last night during down time but i don't expect the same once he gets to basic.
My son left the 13th of April and he used his phone up until that Friday when we got his last call from his cell phone!! We got his first letter this past Monday and he graduates the 25th of June....

Taryn - mail is kind of slow for the first few weeks, as they are still having to sort individually through the battalion to each company and then by platoons, it takes from what I have seen each cycle roughly 2-3 weeks for that to get straightened out...but he can send you letters and you will get those pretty quick, don't be discourage when he asks where your letters are...they are coming slowly. As for phone calls, that just depends on the unit how they handle that, for some it is an earned privilege, for others they could be once a week, just make sure when he calls you are prepared to ask your questions...it could be as simple as a I'm here. Hang in there.
My hubby was only allowed to call 3 times the entire time he was in basic.. 3 minutes per phone call mind you.. so don't be expecting much; communicate through your letters.
Oh and he didnt call until his 7th week in

just heard from my daughter.family day is the 29th and it suspose 2 start no later than 10am so y is it that she cant see us tll 1pm and back by 6pm..and graduation she is not allowed 2 leave till next day when the letter states that if we r taken her then we check her out after graduation..an now they say we can only see here 4 a few hr graduation day?? someone please answer this for me.. sheis FCO 3-13
when i was there for Family Day just 2 weeks ago we didnt have to be off the base untill 9pm. then on Graduation my son was able to leave base and had to be in his Baraks by 9pm that night
Nan, do they get to go home after graduation or do they stay there longer? my wife is there right now and she graduates june 11th.

My son graduated two weeks ago from ft. jack. On family day the soldiers will be able to spend the day with family on base. On grad day they may leave base after ceremony but be in barracks by 9 pm. My son then left for AIT the next day. They eill give your soldier directions but it will be late in her training...Word of warning, the base traffic during family day and grad is really bad, be sure to give enough time to get loved one back to barracks.

Regarding base traffic on Family Day or Graduation Day, plan to get to the gate EARLY- no later than 1 1/2 hours BEFORE you should be there. We stayed at a hotel off exit 9A on I77, left at 7:15 to arrive there by 9am and were almost late. The line at the gate took over 45 mintues to get through.

My son graduated April 9th, my #1 tip is to pack a picnic lunch for family day because every other place is really crowded. I think there is more than one park on base. We went to one with covered picnic tables by a lake, it was beautiful and we got to spend quality time and not waste it standing in lines. Base traffic was really bad after graduation. Take your time and dont rush, rushing is futile! LOL
after graduation do they get to go home if they have a 10 day leave?  and are the hotels on base good? and suggestions on hotels?

Whohooo congrats to those Cadre members who got the EIB!! My husband got his CIB awhile back and I can say it was a very Proud moment for my hubby! 

FYI for those who do not know what it is: 
The EIB is awarded to U.S. Army personnel who hold Infantry or special forces military occupational specialities. To be awarded the EIB, the service member must complete a testing phase which is the culmination of weeks of training, leading to a final evaluation period. The EIB test is administered on the average once per year with pass rates usually averaging less than 10 percent, depending on the unit conducting testing.

February 18, 2010

Fort Jackson, S.C. - In December 2009, five Soldiers were investigated for potential verbal threats against fellow Soldiers. Go early the day of Graduation, the traffic is heavy at the gate !
How early? and how long is graduation?
I would go at least 2 hours before. It lasts maybe a hour

If the weather causes graduation to be moved inside it will be about 30 mins.. They are on a very tight schedule because they can only do 2 companies at a time.. I reccomend parking and walking if you can.. With the traffic coming in for the next graduation ceremony and the traffic going out of the solomon center it got a little ridiculous when my husband graduated.. We got there about 2 hours early on graduation day because it was inside.. We did on family day as well but it is freezing until the sun comes up, so bundle up and take ots of blankets!! It is bleachers as well so seat warmers and stopping at Burger King for coffee is also a good idea.. Or there is a Starbucks on Forest Drive.. You can get away with gettting to Family Day 1.5 hours early but if you want front row seats that is the latest I would get there..

Hi Mary,  From my understanding anyone in Basic during Dec 17th-Jan 3rd will be allowed to go home for the Christmas Exodus.  My Husband just booked his flight today through Victory Travel and it was $505.00 which is the same price that I was able to find it for using all of the normal travel sights.  Victory Travel does have an option on their sight where you can check flight prices so you have an idea of how much it will cost.  Also, soldiers are given the option to have the cost of the flight taken out of their paycheck or pay it with a debit or credit card.  The above link gives a lot of good information if you still have ?'s
was your husband able to call you when he was making the flight at victory travel to let you know what was going on?

no he called me on Friday to get a credit card # and then called on Saturday to tell me they would be booking their flights today.  I had been anxiously awaiting the pending charge on my credit card to make sure the ticket had been booked.  I assume they will be able to call us soon to give us their flight info- at least I hope so. He is in E co. 2-39 4th platoon

my husband is very new.. he started basic on oct. 30th.  im hoping they allow him to call me before he purchases the ticket!  I bet it will make you feel so much better once you see that his ticket is booked :)

yes it did-- Im sure they will let him call you beforehand- the other option is for you to book the ticket through Victory Travel ahead of time just make sure he knows that you already purchased it so you do not end up with 2 tickets.  Jason's commander sent out a form letter that I received on Friday explaining the xmas leave and then he called on Friday- he said his drill sergeant wanted everyone to call their family to tell them they were booking the tickets on Monday.  He got to call me again on Saturday because Im not sure everyone in his unit was able to get ahold of the info they needed on Friday.  You should get a call from him in a couple of days just to let you know he is at least alive- I was able to talk to Jason for 3 minutes when he first started basic.
did you talk to him in reception though too?  I talked to my husband up until thursday and he started on Friday.. thats when you got your first 3 min call?

yes I was able to talk to him everyday while he was in reception and then went he started basi cit was a couple of days before he was able to make that first 3 minute phone call.  Right now they do not get to use their phones very often and they are not given a lot of personal time so it is hard for him to send letters everyday.  I hope that they will be allowed to use their phones more in the future- it is very hard not being able to at least talk to them every day or every other day.  But it does get easier- he has been gone since Sept 27.

Sorry, from the posts I have been reading it appears it is very hard to get in contact with anyone over the phone at Victory. I just messed around on their web page http://fortjacksonmwr.com/travel/ to check out the flight prices.
MayberryTravel.com is a great site to book flights and hotels!!!  They have some great deals!

Good to know! Already have the kids flu shots scheduled before we head up for Fam/Grad Days - gotta wait on the H1N1. HOOAH!!!
Ditto

The H1N1 has not been tested, it has not been approved for humans, it has 400 times the mercury in it that is considered safe...please think about it before you expose your children to it....please educate yourselves....we love our children enough to do that!

HOOAH! I love Mercury! --> seriously, I'm shipping on Oct.13th, let's work on the positive-speak about the H1N1 here. Leadership is doing everything in their power to provide the safest enviroment for us to train in, including the most up to date and effective means of battling flu infections of all sorts.. we can't let these things scare us from serving, there will be far more daunting threats ahead.

The H1N1 is being tested as much as the yearly flu vaccine ever is...the flu vaccine is changed every year according to the predicted strain.  Are you sure about the mercury?  They're telling us different at the clinic where I work.  It's has been approved for humans and is being shipped to various health organizations as we speak.  I look at it like this...if I don't give it to my children and they get infected, possibly die..what kind of parent was I not to give them protection when it was available?  If I do have them get it and there are side effects (God forbid!) at least I was trying to keep them healthy with the best interest in mind.  It's a very hard choice to make....

Here are a couple links to some vaccination facts. With our children in the Army we have no options, with our children at home getting these vaccines is pretty foolish. See facts on how h1n1 differs from other flu vaccines (we don't get those either). 

http://www.nvic.org/NVIC-Vaccine-News/August-2009/Gardasil-Swine-Flu-Vaccines-Inconvenient-Truths.aspx

a second link: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B4SmFxyust0

There are others. Google yourself and do your own research.
This is not about not being positive, it is about being informed.

I have utilized EMDR successfully to combat post traumatic stress disorder. Hippotherapy is also a good option. Giving soldiers time in counseling without stigma attached as well as focusing on helping them realize what they have to live for should all be a part of a positive, effective therapeutic approach to dealing with this common issue.
HOOAH!  I work in behavioral medicine, and I think this initiative is a GIANT step in helping our soldiers through their rough times.  And it IS a common issue, not just with soldiers!
